title: Provides that the state office for the aging shall be deemed a consumer directed personal assistance service provider
summary: Permits the office for the aging to contract for consumer directed personal assistance services through specifically defined models.

BILL NUMBER:S2167

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the elder law, in relation to consumer directed personal
assistance services

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill amends section 214 of the elder law
(the State Office for the Aging statutes), by adding a new
subdivision 8, Consumer-Directed Personal Assistance Service Provider.

(a) Makes SOFA a participating provider for the purposes of providing
consumer directed personal assistance services, and makes the
following further modifications concerning services provided by or
through the office: "eligible individual" is an individual aged sixty
or older who is eligible for long term care and services provided by
a certified home health agency, long term home health care program or
AIDS home care program, or is eligible for personal care services; or
eligible for medical assistance; or has been determined by the social
services district as being in need of home care services or private
duty nursing; "participating provider" means SOFA, its contractors,
and any intermediary service organization. The section provides a
number of models under which services may be provided.

(b) Requires SOFA to file within 120 days an application for a federal
1115 waiver and requires other agencies to comply with any request
for the filing of such waiver if SOFA lacks authority to file itself.
Further requires SOFA to seek to include and provide a seamless
network of other services provided through the office where
appropriate. Establishes principles for the provision of services,
including the principle that individuals have the primary authority
to make choices that work best for them, regardless of the nature or
extent of their disability or the source of payment for services.

(c) Allows SOFA to waive State rules and regulations which inhibit its
ability to provide services, so long as such waiver is consistent
with any federal waiver granted pursuant to Section 1115 of the
Social Security Act or any successor thereto.

(d) Requires SOFA to expand source of payment for the program,
including payments from voluntary and willing private sources,
insurance plans, charities and foundations, and individuals.

(e) Permits SOFA to provide or contract for consumer-directed services
on a statewide basis, but requires the office to coordinate services
with any current provider of consumer directed services. Prohibits a
state agency from imposing a limitation on the number of eligible
individuals served.

(f) Establishes that the consumer-directed program by SOFA shall not
be subject to audit, assessment, suspension, sanction, or report by
a state agency, except that it shall be subject to audit by the
office of the state comptroller to the extent that such programs
would have been subject to audit but for this paragraph.

JUSTIFICATION:
The consumer-directed personal assistance services
program is a marvelous and flexible way of providing services to
individuals, however it is not firmly established with the senior
network, and the range of options and benefits has not been fully
exploited in New York. This legislation serves several goals: by
making SOFA a provider, it will bring the program fully into the
senior services network, and by running this part of the program
under an 1115 waiver, the program will achieve maximum flexibility.
New York has used Medicaid waivers to reorient the state's health
care spending away from inpatient facilities towards delivery
systems focused on outpatient and primary care.  Through this
legislation, we can expand this efficient system to seniors.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
S.457 -  2007-08 - Aging
S.1592 - 2009-10 - Aging

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
To be determined.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediately.
